executive summary.company synopsis: Ag Processing Inc (AGP) is a farmer-owned cooperative established in 1983, engaged in the procurement, processing, marketing, and transportation of grains and grain products. AGP operates ten soybean processing plants across the Midwest, including locations in Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, and South Dakota. The cooperative also runs four soybean oil refineries, three biodiesel production facilities, and a deep-water export facility in Washington state. AGP serves over 150 member cooperatives representing approximately 200,000 farmers throughout the United States.

customer engagement suite.elevator pitch:
With Ag Processing's massive expansion—adding an 11th facility and growing to 200,000+ farmer members—your customer touchpoints are multiplying exponentially. Yet 70% of consumers now expect instant, 24x7 support across channels while agent turnover tops 35% in high-volume centers.

As you scale operations globally, can your current contact infrastructure handle multilingual support for international markets while maintaining the cooperative's commitment to serve members "the first time—every time"?

Google's Customer Engagement Suite offers Dialogflow CX virtual agents supporting 100+ languages—Marks & Spencer deflected 50% of calls in 60 days. Let's explore how this could strengthen your member relationships during this growth phase.
customer engagement suite.key insights:
- AGP's expansion to 11 processing facilities serving 200,000+ farmers creates seasonal contact spikes during harvest periods. Elastic CCaaS provides pay-per-use scaling without fixed licensing costs during agricultural peak seasons.

- With operations across 20+ locations and diverse product lines including AminoPlus® and biodiesel, agents handle complex agricultural inquiries. Agent Assist delivers 90 seconds faster resolutions through live transcription and Smart Reply.

- Managing consistent service quality across AGP's distributed soybean processing plants and cooperative network presents oversight challenges. Quality AI enables 100% automated scoring versus traditional 5% manual sampling methods.

- AGP's international export operations through Port of Grays Harbor require multilingual customer support capabilities for global agricultural markets. Virtual Agents support 100+ languages with 50% call deflection potential.

detailed account intelligence.company description:
Ag Processing Inc (AGP) is a farmer-owned cooperative established in 1983, engaged in the procurement, processing, marketing, and transportation of grains and grain products. AGP operates ten soybean processing plants across the Midwest, including locations in Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, and South Dakota. The cooperative also runs four soybean oil refineries, three biodiesel production facilities, and a deep-water export facility in Washington state. AGP serves over 150 member cooperatives representing approximately 200,000 farmers throughout the United States.

AGP's integrated business model encompasses soybean processing, vegetable oil refining, renewable fuels production, and agricultural products/grain marketing. They operate ten soybean processing plants across the Midwest, producing soybean meal and crude soybean oil. The soybean meal is marketed to domestic and global customers as animal feed, while the crude soybean oil is further refined for use in the food sector and industrial applications, including biofuels. AGP also produces AminoPlus®, a high-performance soy bypass protein product for the dairy industry.
detailed account intelligence.firmographics:
- Company name: Ag Processing

- Country: United States of America

- Establishment year: 1983

- Industry: Agribusiness, Grain and Oilseed Milling

- NAICS code: 311224

- Employee range: 1001-5000

- Turnover/Revenue range: $176.4M-$500M

- Company website: https://www.agp.com/

- Customer focus: B2B

- Target Segment: Ag Processing Inc (AGP) primarily serves B2B customers, including local and regional cooperatives, food manufacturers, and biofuel producers.

business indicators.market development:
- AGP has over 150 member cooperatives representing approximately 200,000 farmers throughout the United States, demonstrating continued cooperative expansion and farmer network growth 

- Export terminal at Port of Grays Harbor serves a crucial role in connecting farmers to global markets, with over $200 million invested since 2001, making it the largest soymeal export facility on the West Coast 

- Expanding U.S. soybean crush capacity to meet renewable diesel feedstock demand, with western U.S. processing locations positioned to supply protein to growing Southeast Asian markets 

- The soybean processing market is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 7.64%, driven by consumer demand for soy-based goods, health and wellness trends, and growth in the livestock feed sector
business indicators.facility expansion and infrastructure de:
- Ongoing expansion of Terminal 4 at the Port of Grays Harbor broke ground in November 2024, expected to be operational by mid-2026 

- AGP is opening its 11th processing facility in David City, NE later this year, with capacity to process over 50 million bushels of soybeans per year and expected to begin operations in 2025 

- The new David City facility is expected to create over 60 jobs and provide market opportunities for soybean growers
business indicators.product development and innovation:
- Continued production and marketing of AminoPlus®, a high-performance soy bypass protein product for the dairy industry 

- Launched AminoPlus®, a high-performance soy bypass protein product for the dairy industry as part of expanding product portfolio 

- Expanded product line to include AminoPlus®, a high-performance soy bypass protein product for the dairy industry
business indicators.operational excellence and capacity:
- Committed to adding value to soybeans grown by U.S. farmers, processing more than 20,000 acres of soybeans each day 

- Currently operates 10 soybean processing plants in Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, and South Dakota, along with four soybean oil refineries and three biodiesel production facilities 

- Ranked as the fourth-largest soybean processor in the U.S. and the largest soybean processor west of the Mississippi River
business indicators.strategic business integration:
- Biodiesel production is a key component of AGP's integrated business strategy, with three facilities processing refined soybean oil into biodiesel, solvents, and adjuvants 

- Continued expansion of biodiesel production strategy, leveraging three biodiesel production facilities to process refined soybean oil into biodiesel, solvents, and adjuvants 

- Integrated business model includes soybean processing, vegetable oil refining, renewable fuels production, and agricultural products/grain marketing
business indicators.community investment and recognition:
- Made a $1.3 million contribution to the Port of Grays Harbor, indicating ongoing infrastructure and community investment 

- Recognized as the 2024 Q4 Member of the Quarter by Greater Grays Harbor, Inc. for commitment to community development

financial overview.company operations:
- AGP is a leading U.S. agribusiness primarily operating as a soybean processor/refiner, producing and marketing soybean meal, refined soybean oil, and biodiesel

- The company operates 10 soybean processing plants across Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, and South Dakota, along with four soybean oil refineries and three biodiesel production facilities

- AGP processes more than 5.5 million acres of members' soybeans annually and is the largest farmer-owned soybean processor in the world, ranking approximately fourth-largest in the US by capacity

- The cooperative is owned by about 180 local and regional cooperatives and represents more than 250,000 farmers in 15 states

- Founded in 1983 as a farmer-owned cooperative

- Recently underwent a leadership change with Chris Schaffer replacing retiring CEO Keith Spackler

competitors.archer daniels midland (adm):
A multinational agribusiness company based in Chicago, Illinois, with 270 plants and 400 procurement facilities, controlling a large segment of global human and animal feed.

**Key Points of Differentiation:**

- Entered the bioeconomy in the mid-2000s with a dedicated Biosolutions segment focused on plant-based offerings

- Specializes in oilseeds and corn processing
competitors.cargill:
A USA-based private global food corporation based in Minnetonka, Minnesota, with over 166,000 employees in 66 countries.

**Key Points of Differentiation:**

- Responsible for about 25% of U.S. grain exports

- Expanding into bioplastics, recently acquiring Arkema to produce bio-based industrial solutions for consumer items
competitors.bunge:
A global presence in the farm-to-consumer food chain, and the world's largest oilseed processor and bottled vegetable oil seller.

**Key Points of Differentiation:**

- Largest producer and supplier of fertilizers to farmers in South America

- Processes oilseeds into vegetable oils and protein meals for food, animal feed, and biofuel industries
A global agribusiness cooperative operating in agriculture and energy sectors, providing crop nutrients, protection, seeds, grains, and energy products.

**Key Points of Differentiation:**

- Offers a diverse range of products including lubricants, propane, and refined fuels

- Provides financial services, hedging, payment solutions, and transportation

industry trends.internet of things (iot) in agriculture: IoT technology provides farmers with real-time data on soil conditions, crop health, and environmental factors. Sensors embedded in IoT devices monitor critical parameters like soil moisture, temperature, and crop health, enabling remote farm management and automated irrigation systems that deliver water efficiently to crops.
industry trends.artificial intelligence in agricultural: AI empowers farmers with real-time insights and predictive analytics, including weather forecasting, crop yield estimation, and pricing trends. Machine learning algorithms can automate the identification of plant and livestock diseases, enabling swift corrective actions.
industry trends.advanced crop genetics: The genetic makeup of crops is undergoing a revolution through technologies like genetic engineering and CRISPR. Scientists can develop plant varieties better equipped to withstand climate challenges, such as crops with drought resistance and built-in pest resistance, reducing the need for chemical pesticides.
industry trends.regenerative agriculture technologies: Regenerative agriculture is emerging as a critical trend, using AI, microbial solutions, and automation to restore soil health. This approach aims to reverse the soil depletion caused by industrial farming, bringing vital bacteria and nutrients back to agricultural lands.

customer engagement suite.detailed reasoning: Ag Processing operates in agribusiness with 1,001-5,000 employees and $176.4M-$500M revenue, falling short of CES's ≥100 agents or ≥2M annual interactions threshold. While they use some Google Cloud services (BigQuery, GCP), their tech stack focuses heavily on agricultural processing systems rather than customer service infrastructure. The company has CX solutions including Salesforce CRM and ServiceNow, but lacks visible contact center technology or customer service pain points. As a B2B agricultural cooperative serving other cooperatives rather than end consumers, their customer interaction volume likely doesn't justify enterprise-level conversational AI investment.
customer engagement suite.factors increasing the score:
- Existing Google Cloud Platform presence with BigQuery implementation

- Multi-cloud environment with AWS and Azure experience shows cloud adoption maturity

- Salesforce CRM integration capability already established

- ServiceNow deployment indicates enterprise software adoption

- Revenue range supports potential enterprise software investments
customer engagement suite.factors decreasing the score:
- B2B agricultural cooperative model suggests limited customer service volume

- Company size and interaction patterns don't align with CES ICP requirements

- Tech stack heavily focused on agricultural processing rather than customer experience

- No visible contact center infrastructure or CCaaS solutions in current stack

- Industry focus on grain processing rather than customer-intensive operations
customer engagement suite.potential next steps:
- Validate actual customer interaction volumes and agent count through discovery call

- Explore whether seasonal peak periods create contact center scaling needs

- Assess multilingual requirements for international agricultural product marketing

it decision maker.talking points:
- With AGP expanding to 11 processing facilities and hiring across operations teams in 2024, Dialogflow CX virtual agents can handle routine farmer inquiries about grain pricing and delivery schedules 24/7, deflecting up to 50% of calls during peak harvest season.

- Your recent leadership changes and 200,000+ farmer network create communication challenges that Agent Assist can solve by providing real-time transcription and smart reply suggestions, reducing call resolution times by up to 90 seconds like Best Buy achieved.

- As AGP processes over 20,000 acres of soybeans daily across multiple states, Conversational Insights can cluster contact trends around grain delivery delays or pricing questions, helping your merchandising teams respond to farmer concerns the same day.

- With new David City facility opening and expanding export operations, multilingual virtual agents can support your international grain marketing efforts across 100+ languages, ensuring consistent service quality as you grow globally.

- Your cooperative structure serving 150+ member cooperatives means Quality AI can automatically score compliance and coaching opportunities across customer interactions, reducing manual QA workload while maintaining agricultural industry standards.

- During seasonal spikes when farmers need immediate market information, elastic CCaaS scales your contact capacity up or down automatically, ensuring you only pay for what you use during peak grain marketing periods.

- With your medium cloud spend across AWS, GCP, and Azure, native BigQuery connectors can integrate agricultural commodity data directly into customer conversations, giving agents instant access to pricing and inventory information without system switching.
it decision maker.probing questions:
- Given your extensive operations across 20+ locations serving over 200,000 farmers and member cooperatives, how are you currently handling the seasonal peaks in customer inquiries during harvest and planting seasons, and what challenges do your support teams face in maintaining consistent service quality across all touchpoints?

- With your recent leadership changes including Mark Sandeen's promotion to Chief Marketing Officer and your continued growth with the new David City facility, how is your customer experience strategy evolving to support both your cooperative members and the broader agricultural community you serve?

- As you expand your product portfolio with innovations like AminoPlus® and grow your biodiesel operations, what specific customer service workflows or knowledge management challenges have emerged when your agents need to support inquiries across such diverse product lines and technical specifications?

- Considering your commitment to serving farmers across 16 states and your emphasis on being "Partners in Food Production," how do you currently measure and ensure consistent service quality across your customer interactions, and what visibility do you have into customer sentiment and satisfaction trends?

- Are you currently using any form of AI-powered virtual agents or chatbots to handle routine customer inquiries about product availability, pricing, or account information across your cooperative network?

- On a scale of 1-5, how would you rate your current ability to automatically scale your customer support capacity during peak agricultural seasons without significantly increasing operational costs?

- Do you have real-time visibility into customer conversation topics and sentiment across all your customer touchpoints, allowing you to proactively identify and address emerging issues before they impact your cooperative members?

- Contact center leads reduce post-call documentation time when Agent Assist generates automatic summaries of complex commodity transactions, freeing agents to handle more member inquiries during peak harvest seasons.
it influencer.probing questions:
- How are your contact center agents currently handling the agricultural commodity inquiries and farmer cooperative questions that come in during peak harvest seasons, and what's your process for ensuring consistent information across your 20+ locations?

- When your agents are supporting both English and non-English speaking farmers from your 200,000+ member network, how do you currently route those calls and what challenges do you face with language barriers?

- What does your typical after-call work look like when agents finish a call about soybean processing or biodiesel inquiries, and how much time are they spending on manual note-taking and data entry?

- How are your supervisors currently monitoring and coaching agents on complex agricultural topics, and what percentage of your daily call volume can your QA team realistically review each week?

- When you need to scale up your contact center capacity during busy agricultural seasons or commodity price fluctuations, what's your current process and how quickly can you add agents?

- How many different systems do your agents need to toggle between when handling calls about your various products like AminoPlus, biodiesel, and grain marketing services?

- What's your current approach to identifying trending issues or common questions coming from your farmer cooperative members, and how do you surface those insights to your operations team?

customer engagement suite.the google advantage:
- Unlike monolithic contact-center stacks that require months of implementation, Google CES delivers Agent Assist in just 10 days and full virtual agents in under 90 days, with pay-per-use pricing that automatically scales—helping organizations like Bell Canada deploy 10,000 agents while saving $20M quarterly.

- While typical CX platforms charge separately for each channel and language, Google CES provides native omnichannel support across 100+ languages for voice, chat, SMS, WhatsApp, and email in a single design—eliminating duplicate bot builds and add-on fees that plague traditional approaches.

- Many AI-powered customer service solutions operate as "black boxes" with rigid intent trees, but Google CES combines Dialogflow CX's rule-based guardrails with Gemini's natural language processing—delivering measurable outcomes like Marks & Spencer's 50% call deflection achieved in just 60 days.
customer engagement suite.objection handling:
**Modular purchase, open formats, and portability**

- Google CES allows you to start with specific modules like virtual agents for farmer inquiries or Agent Assist for your customer service teams, then expand based on ROI validation rather than requiring full-stack commitment

- All conversational AI assets export in standard JSON format with open REST/gRPC APIs, ensuring your investment remains portable if business requirements change across your multi-state operations

- The modular approach aligns with your cooperative structure, allowing different facilities or business units to adopt components at their own pace while maintaining centralized management capabilities

**Deployment speed and required effort**

- Pre-built connectors for common business systems reduce implementation time from months to weeks, allowing rapid deployment across your processing plants and cooperative network

- Dialogflow CX's visual flow builder enables your agricultural specialists to create customer journeys without extensive technical resources, leveraging your existing domain expertise

- Cloud-native architecture eliminates infrastructure setup delays, enabling immediate scaling to support your 200,000+ farmer network and seasonal demand fluctuations

**Global language & omnichannel scalability**

- Dialogflow CX supports 100+ languages out-of-the-box, enabling consistent customer experience for your international export customers and diverse domestic farmer base

- Auto-scaling architecture handles seasonal spikes in agricultural inquiries without manual intervention, crucial during planting and harvest periods when farmer communication peaks

- Unified omnichannel platform consolidates voice, chat, and digital interactions into single workflows, streamlining support for both tech-savvy and traditional agricultural customers

**Integrations and coexistence with existing telephony / CCaaS / CRM stack**

- One-click connectors for Salesforce CRM and ServiceNow enable immediate integration with your existing customer relationship management workflows without disrupting established processes

- API-first architecture coexists with your Oracle E-Business Suite and existing telephony infrastructure, preserving investments in agricultural business systems

- Modular design allows gradual enhancement of current customer service capabilities while maintaining operational continuity across your cooperative network and processing facilities

**Security, data sovereignty, and regulatory compliance**

- Customer-Managed Encryption Keys (CMEK) and VPC Service Controls ensure your farmer and cooperative data remains under your direct control within your own GCP project

- PCI-DSS and HIPAA readiness aligns with food safety certifications like SQF accreditation and GFSI standards that AGP already maintains across processing operations

- Access Transparency provides detailed audit logs for regulatory compliance, supporting your existing quality management systems and cooperative governance requirements

**Pricing model and demonstrated ROI**

- Elastic pay-per-use pricing eliminates upfront licensing costs, allowing you to invest savings into core agricultural processing capabilities and farmer value-add programs

- Agent Assist delivers 30-45% reduction in average handle time, directly reducing operational costs across your customer service operations supporting farmers and cooperative partners

- Bell Canada's demonstrated $20M quarterly savings at 10k-agent scale provides a proven ROI benchmark for large-scale agricultural cooperative implementations

**Hybrid deterministic + generative design for controllability versus "black-box" LLM bots**

- Hybrid architecture combines deterministic rules for critical agricultural processes (pricing, regulations, safety) with generative AI for natural conversation, maintaining control over business-critical interactions

- Visual flow designer allows your agricultural specialists to define exact conversation paths for complex topics like soybean processing, biodiesel regulations, and cooperative membership requirements

- Fallback controls and escalation rules ensure human agents handle sensitive farmer concerns or regulatory questions that require your deep agricultural expertise and cooperative relationship management
